subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Hi
msgSnippet: This brings up an interesting point. I d like to see computers and other electronic devices in Quikscript or Shavian (even if it s just a hack). I once tried
messageBody:
This brings up an interesting point. I'd like to see computers and
other electronic devices in Quikscript or Shavian (even if it's just a
hack). I once tried to transliterate text on my Mac into Shavian, but
the files that contain the text are scattered all over. I finally added
a partial transliteration, but it wasn't recognized. There's a problem
with this kind of thing--ISO language codes don't have anything to do
with writing system, and a language written with more than one script
is supposed to have only one code. Ideally, we should use script codes
in addition to language codes, and there exist such codes, but they're
seldom used.
I had intended to start a project to transliterate Ubuntu into Shavian,
but it needs to have an ISO language code first, which it will never
have because it's not a language. It even has a place in Unicode
already, but script codes, as far as I know, are not implemented.
I've been hacking my iPod like crazy-Linux,
I'm not sure how other operating systems handle languages and
scripts--probably in various different ways. But for those who know
more about Unicode and these systems: Is there a solution at hand, or
will we be waiting for some time for script codes? I could shoehorn
Shavian (and eventually Quikscript, I hope) into my operating system by
replacing another language, but I had hoped to do it more elegantly.

Regards,
Joseph Spicer

On Apr 9, 2006, at 6:45 AM, amd64_hacker wrote:

> Hi,
>
> I'm learning quikscript and I thought I would join your group.
>
> I'm really interested in switching my computer to use quikscript
> natively, I see there is work on a unicode mapping how is that going?
>
> (btw - Hi jennifferjen glad to see another new member :-)

This brings up an interesting point. I'd like to see computers and 
other electronic devices in Quikscript or Shavian (even if it's just a 
hack). I once tried to transliterate text on my Mac into Shavian, but 
the files that contain the text are scattered all over. I finally added 
a partial transliteration, but it wasn't recognized. There's a problem 
with this kind of thing--ISO language codes don't have anything to do 
with writing system, and a language written with more than one script 
is supposed to have only one code. Ideally, we should use script codes 
in addition to language codes, and there exist such codes, but they're 
seldom used.
I had intended to start a project to transliterate Ubuntu into Shavian, 
but it needs to have an ISO language code first, which it will never 
have because it's not a language. It even has a place in Unicode 
already, but script codes, as far as I know, are not implemented.
I've been hacking my iPod like crazy-Linux,
I'm not sure how other operating systems handle languages and 
scripts--probably in various different ways. But for those who know 
more about Unicode and these systems: Is there a solution at hand, or 
will we be waiting for some time for script codes? I could shoehorn 
Shavian (and eventually Quikscript, I hope) into my operating system by 
replacing another language, but I had hoped to do it more elegantly.

Regards,
Joseph Spicer
